markdownRemark.excerpt: The Mystery of "Undefined" A major source of confusion among JavaScript developers is the term “undefined.” Understanding the concept of undefined in JavaScript…
markdownRemark.html:
The Mystery of "Undefined"

A major source of confusion among JavaScript developers is the term “undefined.” Understanding the concept of undefined in JavaScript can be especially difficult if you are new to programming, with its long and complex rules that interact with each other in complex ways. In this article, we'll give an overview of what undefined means in JavaScript, look at some examples, and finish with a few life hacks to help you understand and work with undefined in JavaScript.

What does “undefined” mean in JavaScript?

In JavaScript, the term “undefined” refers to a value that has not been assigned to a variable. A variable can be declared, but not initialized. When a variable is declared without an initial value, the variable is set to “undefined”. Think of it like an empty box — it’s possible to tell a box is empty, even though there’s no contents inside of it.

Undefined can also result from referencing an object property or method that doesn’t exist. For example, if you try to access a property of an object that doesn’t exist, the result would be undefined.

When Does “undefined” Show Up in Your Code?

Undefined often appears in return expressions. When a function doesn’t explicitly return anything (or returns undefined or null), it will be treated as if the function returned undefined. It’s important to note that this is not the same as not returning anything; not returning anything is an error.

Also, when the type of a variable is not known (for example, when it’s returned from a function), it will be treated as if its type is “undefined”.

How Can You Spot "undefined" In Your Code?

One way to spot undefined variables in your code is to look for any undefined variables. To do this, you can use the typeof operator. This operator will return “string” if the variable is assigned a string, “boolean” if the variable is assigned a boolean, etc. If it returns “undefined”, then you’ve found a variable that’s been declared but not initialized.

Another way to spot undefined variables is to use the strict equality operator (===). This will compare two values to see if they are exactly the same, and will return false if one of the values is undefined. For example, the following code will return false because one of the values is undefined:

let x = undefined;
let y = 0;
console.log(x === y); // returns false

Life Hacks For Working With "undefined"

If your code contains undefined variables, you need to think about how to fix the problem. Here are a few life hacks to help you:

  • Initialize all variables: Be sure to initialize all variables when you declare them. Otherwise, JavaScript will assign them a value of “undefined”, which can lead to unexpected behavior.
  • Use typeof: typeof can be a useful tool to help you find undefined variables, as well as other types of variables.
  • Use ===: The strict equality operator (===) can also be used to spot undefined variables.
  • Use try-catch: If you’re working with functions that may throw errors, you should use a try-catch statement to catch any errors that may be thrown. This will help you prevent unexpected behavior.

Conclusion

Understanding the concept of undefined in JavaScript is important for any programmer. By following the life hacks listed above, you can quickly and easily detect and debug undefined variables in your code. Once you understand the concept of undefined, you can use it to prevent unexpected behavior in your code.
